channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Organic Farms Become a Winner in Putin’s Feud With the West
item.description: With often cheaper imports unavailable, some agricultural activists hope to see a boost in local farming, but for consumers the self-imposed sanctions have so far served mostly to raise food prices.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boris Akimov, who runs LavkaLavka, an organic farm cooperative, hopes that with the ban on Western imports, Russians will explore local foods.

item.title: Protesters Attempt to Break Into the Hong Kong Legislature
item.description: Demonstrators thought to be from a more militant protest group smashed windows, and the main student groups leading the sit-ins distanced themselves from the actions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Workers checked a broken window of the government headquarters in the Admiralty district of Hong Kong on Wednesday. A small group attempted to break into the city's legislature.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Umbrellas Come Out at Hong Kong Graduation Ceremonies
item.description: The president of Hong Kong Baptist University, Albert Chan, refused to hand out diplomas to students who carried umbrellas onto the stage during graduation ceremonies.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Bangladesh Intercepts Ship Holding 600 Trafficking Victims
item.description: The passengers aboard the ship, mostly from Bangladesh or Myanmar, had been heading to Malaysia, the Bangladeshi Navy said.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: 2 Arrested in Disappearance of Miss Honduras and Her Sister
item.description: The police said they arrested two suspects Tuesday in the disappearance last Thursday of Miss Honduras, María José Alvarado, 19, and her sister Sofía, 23.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: U.N. Urges Arab World to Denounce Islamic State
item.description: The United Nations’ top human rights official on Tuesday called on the Security Council to back efforts to overturn the extremist group’s “ideology of violence.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: News Analysis: In Jerusalem’s ‘War of Neighbors,’ the Differences Are Not Negotiable
item.description: The dispute between Israel and the Palestinians over the holy site at the heart of a recent violent escalation in Jerusalem appears to be turning into an outright religious war.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Supporters of a Palestinian militant group celebrating the deaths in the synagogue attack.

item.title: Israel Shaken by 5 Deaths in Synagogue Assault
item.description: Four men, including three Americans, were killed when two Palestinian assailants stormed a synagogue. A police officer and the attackers also died.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Anti-E.U. Party in Britain Strives for Wider Clout
item.description: Even as it stands a good chance to win a second seat in Parliament, the U.K. Independence Party has lost the support of its founder, who deplores it as xenophobic.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Outside the U.K. Independence Party office in Rochester, in southeastern England.

item.title: Jewish Victims, All From One Jerusalem Street, Were a Congregation’s ‘Wise Scholars’
item.description: Four Jewish men killed Tuesday while praying at their neighborhood synagogue all lived on the same block, and three were rabbis — one the scion of a celebrated Hasidic dynasty.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER, TIMOTHY WILLIAMS and JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:description: The funeral of Rabbi Moshe Twersky, below, one of four men killed Tuesday in their synagogue. A Druse traffic officer died outside.

item.title: Open Source: Norwegian Filmmakers Apologize for Fake Syria Video
item.description: A short film, shot in the style of witness video from Syria and posted on YouTube, provoked a torrent of criticism.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Paris Journal: In a City Wary of Skyscrapers, a New Tower May Rise
item.description: Plans for a 42-story landmark in a somewhat undistinguished part of Paris have raised the alarm for traditionalists who have not approved a new skyscraper in four decades.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Herzog & de Meuron, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A computer image of the proposed Triangle Tower in Paris. Supporters say it would bring jobs and rejuvenate the neighborhood.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: German Official Expresses ‘No Optimism’ on Ukraine Conflict
item.description: Germany’s foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, alluded to the standoff between Russia and Ukraine in grim tones on Tuesday after talks in Moscow with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Romania: Foreign Minister Resigns
item.description: Romania’s foreign minister, Teodor Melescanu, resigned Tuesday, barely a week after taking office, after thousands of citizens living outside the country were unable to vote in last weekend’s presidential runoff election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Uganda: Inquiry Into Ivory Theft Opens
item.description: Uganda said Tuesday that it was investigating the theft of almost 3,000 pounds of ivory from the vaults of its state-run wildlife protection agency and had suspended five staff members.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Plan for Antarctic Whale Hunt Slashes Target Numbers for Catch
item.description: Japan has slashed its whale catch target in the Antarctic by two-thirds in a bid to resume its annual whale hunt, which an international court ruled must stop.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: Report Criticizes Police Killings
item.description: Human Rights Watch asserted in a report that the police in the Democratic Republic of Congo’s capital, Kinshasa, had killed at least 51 unarmed people, including five teenagers, during a three-month crackdown against organized crime.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: United Nations Urges North Korea Prosecutions
item.description: The vote by a General Assembly committee came nine months after a panel of inquiry said North Korean leaders could be held criminally responsible.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Calling Early Elections in Japan, Abe Rolls the Dice on the Economy
item.description: The prime minister’s pledge to hold elections next month reflects worries that his economic revival program and his popularity are faltering, experts say.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.S. Agencies Review Policy on Hostages
item.description: The review includes how the government deals with hostage’s relatives, but a prohibition on paying ransom is not being reconsidered.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Test for Premier, Italians Rally Against Plan to Relax Labor Rules
item.description: A tentative plan by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi that could roll back some worker protections has drawn tens of thousands to the streets.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Trade union members joined a rally in central Rome last month protesting changes to the national jobs law.

item.title: Colombian Forces Search for General Seized by Rebels
item.description: The rebel group issued a statement from the site of the negotiations calling the general and two others seized with him “enemy military personnel.”
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Square Feet: A One-Bedroom Apartment That Could Fit in a Bedroom
item.description: A 275-square-foot microflat in the city sold for $722,000, and developers are building even smaller units in a gravity-defying housing market.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 434-square-foot show apartment in Le Riviera, overlooking Hong Kong's Victoria Harbor.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Protecting Data From Its Snatchers
item.description: Internet companies are facing tough questions over whether they are on the side of government or consumers when it comes to data protection.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Jerusalem Synagogue Victim Descended From Storied Dynasty of Hasidic World
item.description: Rabbi Moshe Twersky was the grandson of a Hasidic grand rabbi who settled in the United States decades before the end of World War II.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER
item.media:description: Ultra-Orthodox Jews mourned during a eulogy ceremony before the funeral of the rabbi Moshe Twersky on Tuesday in Jerusalem.
